subs.text: @Ww3Real I think my grandfather, who spent WWII in some civilian economic planning capacity, would be interested in economic stats: productive workers, mineral resources, fuel supplies, etc. can’t really see how Europe can hold out absent access to high tech factories and supplies.

subs.text: @rabbijilljacobs @truahrabbis I kinda was for a year. Worked for a Jewish startup in 95 funded by an Israeli who had made a small fortune as the US agent of a Russian who was making a large fortune by being given a “privatized” aluminum mine that had previously belonged to the state at fire sale prices.

subs.text: @JosieBrendaA @JewWhoHasItAll @JewishConnectiv The latter being an undercelebrated holiday that deserves to be commercialized. I notice that this year it falls on Flag Day, which one assumes is Xian Simchas Torah. Great crossover potential there.

subs.text: @trekonomics We all grow up with pre-enlightenment values, assuming the world we see as children is how it must be. Learning otherwise requires a combination of good education, good community, good politics, and good therapy.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics We all grow up with pre-enlightenment values, assuming the world we see as children is how it must be. Learning otherwise requires a combination of good education, good community, good politics, and good therapy.

subs.text: @trekonomics I remember being disturbed that my mom and my best friend’s mom — the two of them best friends themselves — had differing policies n whether one should play in the yard barefoot or with socks.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics I remember being disturbed that my mom and my best friend’s mom — the two of them best friends themselves — had differing policies n whether one should play in the yard barefoot or with socks.

subs.text: @trekonomics Not unrelated to the debate among 17th century rabbis as to whether one should light Hanukkah candles from right to left or vice versa — with the unexamined assumption that there was a right way and a wrong way.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics Not unrelated to the debate among 17th century rabbis as to whether one should light Hanukkah candles from right to left or vice versa — with the unexamined assumption that there was a right way and a wrong way.
